Specific Details: Irish business priorities for the future of Europe
DPOs Lobbied: Helen McEntee|Minister of State|Department of Foreign Affairs::Aingeal O'Donoghue|Assistant Secretary|Department of Foreign Affairs
Subject Matter: Irish business priorities for the future of Europe
Intended Results: Inform on business priorities in relation to the future of Europe debate:::Secure commitment for continued support for the digital single market and digitalisation which will create opportunities for citizens across Europe::Communicate the business position that EU member states should continue pursue sovereign tax strategies to meet their economic needs.::Secure better regulation at EU level: EU regulation should harness innovation not hamper it::Achieve flexibility under EU fiscal rules given that at any point in time the economic needs of member states can be different. For example, affording flexibility under fiscal rules and the Stability and Growth Pact would allow Ireland an opportunity to invest in growth-enabling infrastructure developments, while also ensuring fiscal responsibility.::Inform on business priorities on member state competency to design labour market and social policy: The EU should focus on its core competencies and objectives, and avoid legislating in areas where member states are better placed to act. In key areas of social policy, for example, local labour market needs mean that decisions should be left to national governments.::Enhance global trade and investment policy. The EU should continue to advance ambitious, balanced trade deals with key partners. This should include a comprehensive and ambitious future trading relationship with the UK, as well as advancing and implementing deeper trading and investment partnerships with the US, Canada and Japan. Trade policy should be designed for the 21st century, facilitating cross-border data flows and unlocking the potential of EU busin

Specific Details: Limitations in the Domestic Violence Act 2018  as  it does not include perpetrators who are not, or who have not been, in an  intimate relationship with the victim. The 1997 Act is  compromised by providing that  prosecution will only take place for the most severe, blatant and violent  examples of coercive control. The legislation needs  to have a comprehensive definition of ‘coercive control’ in all its forms,  including the very high incidence of psychological abuse and abusive behaviour.

Specific Details: Meeting with Minister for Justice Helen McEntee
DPOs Lobbied: Helen McEntee|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Meeting with Minister for Justice Helen McEntee
Intended Results: Discuss IPRT penal reform priorities with Minister for Justice Helen McEntee to make her aware of our key concerns.
Lobbying Activities: IPRT's Executive Director and Legal & Public Affairs Manager met Minister for Justice Helen McEntee on 9 November 2022 to discuss key IPRT penal reform priorities prior to her going on maternity leave at the end of November 2022. Key issues discussed included: Review of Penal Policy Options; Final Report and Recommendations of the High Level Task Force; Inspection of Places of Detention Bill 2022; Criminal Justice (Community Sanctions) Bill 2014; Criminal Justice (Rehabilitative Periods) Bill 2018; IPRT report on rights of people detained in Central Mental Hospital; potential for extending parole to long-sentenced prisoners by way of regulation; and overcrowding and staff shortages in prisons.|Meeting|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Saoirse Brady, Executive Director, and Molly Joyce, Legal & Public Affairs Manager

Lobbyist Name: SAFE Ireland National Social Change Agency CLG  T/A SAFE Ireland
Specific Details: Zero Tolerance Strategy on Domestic, Sexual and Gender Based Violence
DPOs Lobbied: Helen McEntee|Minister|Department of Justice
Subject Matter: Zero Tolerance Strategy on Domestic, Sexual and Gender Based Violence
Intended Results: Ensure implementation of provisions within the Third National Strategy on Domestic, Sexual and Gender based violence thus securing better outcomes for women and children victim/survivors.
Lobbying Activities: Email dated 18th July from CEO Mary McDermott to Minister McEntee with Safe Ireland considerations on structural issues of the domestic, sexual and gender based violence infrastructural response in Ireland. Specific Details: Highlight recommendations of Prison Overcrowding Response Group and inform work of subsequent Future Prison Capacity Working Group
DPOs Lobbied: Helen McEntee|Minister|Department of Justice::Deirdre McDonnell|Assistant Secretary|Department of Education::Don Culliton|Director of Services or Equivalent|Irish Prison Service
Subject Matter: Highlight recommendations of Prison Overcrowding Response Group and inform work of subsequent Future Prison Capacity Working Group
Intended Results: Implementation of the Prison Overcrowding Response Group recommendations and to inform the work of the Future of Prison Capacity Working Group to address the prison overcrowding crisis and implement existing progressive policy particularly around reducing the number of people imprisoned for short periods and refocus resources on community-based alternatives and preventative measures.
Lobbying Activities: Wrote to Minister of Justice on 16 October 2024 asking her to implement Prison Overcrowding Response Group's key recommendations, particularly legislative measures including changes to eligibility for Temporary Release and parole, incorporating the principle of prison as a sanction of last resort in law and progressing the Criminal Justice (Community Sanctions) Bill 2014. Also engagement with the judiciary in an appropriate manner which respects their independence in relation to short sentences.|Letter|1::Asked Senator Lynn Ruane to highlight the Prison Overcrowding Response Group report in the Seanad. |Phone call|2-5::Executive Director presented to Working Group on Future Prison Capacity on 5 November 2024 calling for reduction in prison capacity through alternative measures, ensuring policy decisions are evidence-informed and based on robust data, ensuring that capacity planning is human rights based and the need to take a long-term approach to future proofing the prison system by reducing imprisonment rates and redirecting resources to social services, health treatment and community based sanctions.|Meeting|1::Brief follow-up submission made to Working Group on Future Prison Capacity with key IPRT asks as outlined during presentation.|Submission|1
